content.question: A block attached to a spring is held at position <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and released. The block then undergoes simple harmonic motion along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis. The force exerted on the block by the spring as a function of the blockâ€™s position <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> is represented by the graph. Which of the following positions, if any, corresponds to the equilibrium position of the spring-block system?

choices.label: <math alttext="0.0 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>
<math alttext="0.50 meters " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>
<math alttext="1.0 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>
There is no equilibrium position because the force is nonzero at <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="0.50 meters " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
